item.title: Storming a Spanish Border in North Africa
item.description: More than 1,000 would-be immigrants tried to forced their way over razor-wire barriers into Spain’s North African enclave of Melilla on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
item.media:description: Over 1,000 migrants tried to scale barriers to Spain’s North African enclave of Melilla on Wednesday. About half made it; some were beaten back by the police.

item.title: News Analysis: Rebutting Critics, Obama Seeks Higher Bar for Military Action
item.description: The United States should avoid getting dragged into the quicksand of international crises that have trapped some of his predecessors, expressed President Obama on Wednesday.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: At West Point, President Obama talked about being “haunted” by the deaths of four cadets.

item.title: World Briefing: Central African Republic: Deadly Attack at Church
item.description: Muslim rebels stormed a Catholic church compound in Bangui, the capital, on Wednesday in a deadly attack with gunfire and grenades, witnesses said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Iran: MERS Virus Reaches Its 20th Country
item.description: A deadly virus that originated in Saudi Arabia two years ago has reached Iran, infecting two sisters in Kerman, the health ministry reported.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Lawmakers Ask State Dept. to Review Support for Honduras
item.description: More than 100 members of Congress, outlining the deteriorating human rights situation in Honduras, called for pressure on the Honduran government.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Snowden Says He Was a Spy, Not Just an N.S.A. Analyst
item.description: In an interview with NBC News, Edward J. Snowden said American officials were trying to play down the importance of his intelligence jobs.
item.dc:creator: By ELENA SCHNEIDER and STEVE KENNY
item.media:description: Edward J. Snowden made his latest claims, including that he had worked under assumed names overseas for the C.I.A. and N.S.A., in a television interview with Brian Williams of NBC News.

item.title: Spanish Upstart Party Said It Could, and Did. Now the Hard Part Begins.
item.description: An anti-establishment, anti-austerity movement is trying to go beyond simply tapping into a nation’s anger.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Libyan Strongman Battles Militias for Control
item.description: Gen. Khalifa Hifter is gaining support from some Libyans who may have their misgivings but want to see an end to the chaotic violence blamed on local militias.
item.dc:creator: By OSAMA AL-FITORY and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Gen. Khalifa Hifter has cast himself as the protector who will beat back Libya’s militias and rid the country of extremists.

item.title: U.S. Alleged to Join in Plot in Venezuela
item.description: Accusations to kill President Nicolás Maduro came against the ambassador to Colombia as Washington considered freezing assets of Venezuelan officials.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Amid Drawdown, Fears of Taliban Resurgence and Economic Collapse
item.description: Officials and business leaders in Afghanistan believe that too few American troops are being left behind for too few years.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: Afghan soldiers at a training facility last year. President Obama announced on Tuesday that the United States would withdraw nearly all troops from Afghanistan by the end of 2016.

item.title: News Analysis: Rebutting Critics, Obama Seeks Higher Bar for Military Action
item.description: The United States should avoid getting dragged into the quicksand of international crises that have trapped some of his predecessors, expressed President Obama on Wednesday.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: At West Point, President Obama talked about being “haunted” by the deaths of four cadets.

item.title: Leader of French Far-Right Hopes to Fix Europe From the Inside
item.description: Marine Le Pen, the leader of France’s National Front, outlined ambitions to reshape Europe’s direction during her visit to Brussels.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: “The model of a totalitarian, technocratic Europe is now out of date,” Marine Le Pen said in Brussels on Wednesday.

item.title: Terror’s Front: Local Groups, Eyes on West
item.description: Decentralized Qaeda affiliates and extremists now pose “the most direct threat” to the United States and American interests abroad, the president said Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Mohamed al-Zahawi, leader of Ansar al-Shariah, the Benghazi militia blamed for the 2012 attack on the American diplomatic compound.

item.title: Suicide Bomber in Syria Was U.S. Citizen, Officials Say
item.description: The bomber is believed to be the first American involved in such an attack, U.S. officials said.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT and BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Syria to Miss Deadline On Weapons, Official Says
item.description: In a May 23 letter to the Security Council, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said that roughly 8 percent of the chemical stockpile remained in Syria, awaiting shipment for destruction abroad.
item.category: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Obama Warns U.S. Faces Diffuse Terrorism Threats
item.description: President Obama said the United States could play a vital role in world affairs without resorting to unilateral force or retreating to isolationism.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: The Extremist Organizations ‘on the Front Lines’
item.description: Islamic extremism has decentralized over the past decade. Some groups have links to Al Qaeda, but most of them focus more on waging local battles than on attacking the West.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and SHREEYA SINHA

item.title: Turnout Rises in Egypt, but the Vote Raises Doubts
item.description: Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, the former army field marshal who led last summer’s military takeover, won election as president with more than 90 percent of the vote, according to preliminary tallies.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: The vote was universally expected to confer the presidency to Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, but the unexpectedly low turnout has threatened to undercut Mr. Sisi’s claims that his actions represented the ardent demand of Egypt’s vast majority.

item.title: Open Source: Israel Suspends Soldier in West Bank Shooting Investigation
item.description: An Israeli soldier from a communications unit charged with documenting the work of combat troops was suspended for firing his rifle during a protest.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Syrians in Lebanon Flood Polling Place, Choosing Assad Out of Fervor or Fear
item.description: Thousands of Syrians who have fled to Lebanon were among expatriates participating in an election expected to return President Bashar al-Assad to power.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Syrian voters at the embassy in Baabda, Lebanon, just outside of Beirut, with flags covered in pictures of President Bashar al-Assad.

item.title: Yalta Journal: Crimean Vineyards of Last Czar Withstand Time and Tumult
item.description: Founded by Czar Nicholas II in 1894, the Massandra vineyards carry a time capsule of Russian and world history in their expansive cellars.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: A 1936 law preserves the cellars of Massandra under state protection. “Massandra is a different country,” says Nikolay Boyko, the winery’s director general.

item.title: Presidential Building Is Stormed in Restless Georgian Region
item.description: The embattled president of Abkhazia, a breakaway enclave of Georgia, called the action an armed power grab. But opposition leaders disputed his account.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Protesters gathered peacefully outside the presidential headquarters in Sukhumi, the capital of Abkhazia, on Wednesday.

item.title: After Months of Infighting, a Major Faction Splits From the Pakistani Taliban
item.description: The Sajna faction said the broader militant group led by Maulana Fazlullah had fallen under the control of “invisible hands.”
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN and DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Russians Revealed Among Ukraine Fighters
item.description: A disclosure by the mayor of Donetsk of Russian nationals among the fighters further muddies a murky picture of the complex connections and allegiances that are beginning to form.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH and SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.media:description: Unloading the bodies of pro-Russian fighters in Donetsk, Ukraine, on Tuesday. Russia has denied its regular soldiers are part of the conflict in east Ukraine.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Nobel Laureate’s Release from Prison May Hinge on His ‘Regret’
item.description: Liu Xiaobo, who was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 2011 and is serving an 11-year prison term for subversion, is the world’s only jailed Nobel laureate. On June 8, under Chinese law, he become eligible for parole.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
